dt: {bc}to crush or burden by abuse of power or authority

dt.t: The country has long been {wi}oppressed{/wi} by a ruthless dictator.

dt: {bc}to burden spiritually or mentally {bc}weigh heavily upon

pt: {sc}wrong{/sc} {sc}oppress{/sc} {sc}persecute{/sc} {sc}aggrieve{/sc} mean to injure unjustly or outrageously. {sc}wrong{/sc} implies inflicting injury either unmerited or out of proportion to what one deserves.

pt.t: a penal system that had {it}wronged{/it} him

pt: {sc}oppress{/sc} suggests inhumane imposing of burdens one cannot endure or exacting more than one can perform.

pt.t: a people {it}oppressed{/it} by a warmongering tyrant

pt: {sc}persecute{/sc} implies a relentless and unremitting subjection to annoyance or suffering.
{sc}aggrieve{/sc} implies suffering caused by an infringement or denial of rights.

pt.t: a legal aid society representing {it}aggrieved{/it} minority groups

et: Middle English {it}oppressen{/it} "to put pressure on, crush, burden, overwhelm," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}oppresser,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}oppressāre,{/it} frequentative derivative from Latin {it}oppressus,{/it} past participle of {it}opprimere{/it} "to press on, stifle, overpower," from {it}ob-{/it} {et_link|ob-|ob-} + {it}premere{/it} "to press" {ma}{mat|press:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: to crush or burden by abuse of power or authority
to burden spiritually or mentally : weigh heavily upon
